dialogues.Benedict:
[1]  
[2]The Baldwins. 
[3]We had dinner with them three years ago. You talked about your parent's anniversary. 
[4]I'm getting married next month. 
[5]Well, I hope Danny is as good as he thinks he is. A bouquet toss in prison can get pretty ugly. 
[6]  
[7]Four weeks. 
[8]I heard what you said, Frank. Did you hear what I said? 
[9]What can I say? You're a funny guy. 
[10]Look at it this way...Eugene....if the album goes platinum it'll cover what you owe. And if the second one goes gold, that should cover the interest. 
[11]  
[12]Yes. 
[13]You want it in writing? 
[14]You're clean. 
[15]As soon as someone retaliates, the situation is out of control. 
[16]There's plenty for everyone. 
[17]Sharing is good.
dialogues.Rusty:
[1]You are kidding me. 
[2]  
[3]736.18 degrees Fahrenheit, Felix. I watched it. 
[4]I want what I paid for. 
[5]No, Felix, no. I paid for pure. And if my workshop were on top of Mount Everest it would be pure. But I'm at sea level, Felix, and at sea level it should liquefy at 736.95. If it's pure, that is. Which this isn't. 
[6]Let me ask you something: When Christo calls his cotton supplier and asks for 100% cotton cloth, do you think his supplier sends him 98% cotton and 2% polyester and when that doesn't work, says to Christo, "Well, you should have told me you were going to wrap the coast of Australia"? 
[7]Felix, you're in a shame spiral. Have your assistant lose my number. 
[8]My god. 
[9]How long you gonna give us? 
[10]We're on the five o'clock. 
[11]Amsterdam. 
[12]

[24]A doctor who specializes in skin diseases will dream that he has fallen asleep in front of the television. Later he will wake up in front of the television but not remember his dream.

[50]Jesus. This'll kill us. 
[51]It's like blood in the water for these guys.

[63]We're here.

[65]It's only a few inches.

[67]Not true. Palowski did it in `64 in Venice and `73 in Istanbul.

[69]The good news is, after the first twelve hours, I stopped being able to smell anything. 
[70]This water was stagnant six hundred years ago.

[81]--I was just checking up on her. I knew she didn't want to see me. I was being polite.

[98]All right, let's stay calm. We don't need to over-react here. He said some disrespectful things, that's true. But why antagonize this guy? Why get into something with him? He's young and he's filthy rich, and he's got time on his hands. We don't want to become his Betty noir. We can just fence his painting and earn a lot more than we would have from the certificate. 
[99]We'll make enough selling the Degas to pay off her buyer-- 
[100]Saul?

[107]163.

[109]This mentor of yours...was he a good thief in his day?

dialogues.Isabel:
[1]Let's discuss, briefly and to begin, with the category of "thieves", as distinguished from the larger category of what might be termed "hardened" criminals. The highest level, "master thieves," if you will, is a very small world. Between six and ten high-level crews are operating in Europe at any given time. Worldwide, no more than twenty. The most famous, Gaspar LeMarc, is either dead or retired, and the expectation is that no one will replace him. The good news is the trend is toward their extinction. 
[2]For example: Anecdotal evidence suggest these people are personally insufferable. 
[3]Their egos demand constant praise, and they embellish their exploits to anyone who will listen. They tell their own stories endlessly, provided of course, they are talking to a fellow thief or an intimate. 
[4]Those who interact with them on a personal level are relegated to positions of total servitude, with no chance for growth or freedom. Their lives are treated as secondary. Many of them suffer from depression. It's a crime for which there is no law, and yet causes untold damage. 
[5](amplified by the lectern 
[6]That's impossible! 
[7]I hope the scene hasn't been contaminated. 
[8]No forced entry. 
[9]No, that would have triggered the system. 
[10]And damaged the circuits. 
[11]They had to have known the code. 
[12]There are other ways to get the code. Closed loop. Redundant servers. Titanium encasement. Not bad. 
[13]Uh...well, they probably set up in a house across the canal and watched him type the code in through a pair of binoculars. 
[14]That's why they probably set up over there-- 
[15]--And used the mirror. 
[16]I'm guessing they'd need a fifteen hundred millimeter lens to get a clear shot but-- 
[17]It's where the crossbow bolt hit. 
[18]Ever heard of Franz Schuman? 
[19]They would have fired from that roof. Through this open window. 
[20]Not a cop, anyway. 
[21]Sorry. Your friend downstairs put me in a bad mood. 
[22]Yes. You're right. 
[23]But these man are exceptionally good. Even when they make mistakes. 
[24]When did he get up and notice the certificate was gone? 
[25]But the alarm would have been-- 
[26]Oh... Oh, I know what happened. 
[27]There was someone else. 
[28]Oh, I wish I could've have seen that. 
[29]That must have really been something. 
[30]I'm sure there's another scenario that would fit these physical details, but I don't know what it is. 
[31]You can start by picking that guy up. 
[32]Can I speak to him? 
[33]Oh no. I just need to speak with him. To get some information. 
[34]I'm sure. I only need a moment, then I'll be out of your way. 
[35] 
[36]  
[37]Is it? Because you've been seeing a lot of me lately. 
[38]You were sitting in a Mercedes outside my apartment on Wednesday night. 
[39]You were hiding in the bushes when I had lunch yesterday at Trattoria Bella. 
[40]This one...I'm not even sure where this one was taken, but I like it a lot. Very Ron Gallela. 
[41]I mean, if I didn't know better I'd think you all came here to steal the Vanderspeigle Getuigschrift, also known as the world's first stock certificate. You must have been so proud of yourselves. A Schuman Special. It's been awhile. That was a very handsome crossbow shot, Eugene. 
[42]And the Palowski...whose idea was that? 
[43]Oh...I know you didn't. Somebody beat you to it. One man. No crew. No back up. Tell me something -- just so I can get the full picture in my head -- was he wearing a tuxedo? A white dinner jacket? 
[44]So you know who he is? 
[45]Well, then. I'll see you when you see him. To get your certificate back. 
[46]Twenty-four hours. You know that. 
[47]I don't have twenty-four hours. They're there now. They'll lead me to him. 
[48]You also know that you can go now, if you don't take your secretary. When there's liability, I need a document. 
[49]Yes.
